bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. George Carroll, December 3, 1953

div1.p: Hench requests permission to examine the material concerning her late father-in-law, James Carroll. He hopes to meet with her during his next trip to Washington, D.C.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. George Carroll, December 3, 1953
div1.opener:
December 3, 1953
Mrs. George S. H. Carroll
2814 Rhode Island Avenue N.E.
Washington 18, D. C.
My dear Mrs. Carroll:
div1.p:
I certainly appreciate your letter of November 4. I am distressed to
know of your confusion and lonesomeness but of course this is quite
understandable. Fortunately, time tends to heal all things and I do
hope and pray that as time passes you will become more and more interested
in the life of your relatives and friends and in that way the sorrow
will be lessened.

Since writing you, I have been invited to speak at the Walter Reed Hos-
pital February 18. If you expect to be in Washington at that time, I
should like to visit you to pay my respects and perhaps to discuss some
of the matters mentioned in your letter. I agree that the Army Museum
has a right to receive whatever you, as the widow choose to let them
have and it would seem to me that would be the place for the medal since
Doctor Carroll worked there. Perhaps the Army Museum would make either
a nice photographic copy of the medal for the various relatives, or they
might even consider making a plaster model of the medal, if you and Mr.
Carroll's sisters would give the original to the Army Museum. This is
merely a thought on my part. I know some men at the Army Museum, indeed
I know General DeCoursey, the Director, and if you wish me to do so I
will be glad to sound him out on the matter, but I will not do it without
your permission.

As for the other things, certainly you, as the widow, have the right to
do with them as you wish. As I have told you, I do so very much hope that
you will permit me just to examine the material. I only have one pur-
pose and that is to be as accurate as I possibly can in describing in
my book exactly what Doctor Carroll and each of the other men did. I
am hoping very much that you will find with your husband's souvenirs
of his father an important notebook which was kept by one of the Yellow
Fever Board and which apparently later was borrowed by Doctor Carroll
to use for his notes. There are in this notebook some unused notes
which I am anxious to study.

Do you expect to be in Washington throughout February? If so, I shall
arrange to stay over in Washington an extra day so as to visit with you
and perhaps give whatever helpful suggestions I can with regard to the
very valuable souvenirs of Doctor Carroll's work.

Since you are under the care of a physician I should not presume to
give you advice regarding your own arthritis unless your physician
should wish me to act in the double capacity of a friend and a con-
sultant as well.

Cortisone when taken properly can be very helpful indeed but like all
hormones, it must be taken indefinitely. Nevertheless by certain tricks
we have learned the last year or so, we have been able to lower the dose
notably in many patients and some have been able to discontinue it, at
least for certain lengths of time.

I wish I could advise you regarding the foot operation but I cannot do
this without seeing you as a patient. You seem to have excellent ad-
vice but I can understand that you hesitate to have any operation un-
less it is necessary. So often the feet of arthritic patients are
badly deformed and do need surgery if the proper supports are inade-
quate.

I shall await a reply from you with interest and do hope that I can
see you in February.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
